t: Luke 13
Repent or Perish
At*p that time, some people came and reported to him about the Galileans whose blood Pilate had mixed with their sacrifices.
And he responded to them, “Do*r you*r think*r that*r these*r Galileans*r were*r more*r sinful*r than*r all*r the*r other*r Galileans*r because*r they*r suffered*r these*r things?*r
No,*r I*r tell*r you;*r but*r unless*r you*r repent,*r you*r will*r all*r perish*r as*r well.*r

Or*r those*r eighteen*r that*r the*r tower*r in*r Siloam*r fell*r on*r and*r killed -*r do*r you*r think*r they*r were*r more*r sinful*r than*r all*r the*r other*r people*r who*r live*r in*r Jerusalem?*r
No,*r I*r tell*r you;*r but*r unless*r you*r repent,*r you*r will*r all*r perish*r as*r well.”*r
The Parable of the Barren Fig Tree
And*p he told this parable: “A*r man*r had*r a*r fig*r tree*r that*r was*r planted*r in*r his*r vineyard.*r He*r came*r looking*r for*r fruit*r on*r it*r and*r found*r none.*r

He*r told*r the*r vineyard*r worker,*r ‘Listen,*r for*r three*r years*r I*r have*r come*r looking*r for*r fruit*r on*r this*r fig*r tree*r and*r haven’t*r found*r any.*r Cut*r it*r down!*r Why*r should*r it*r even*r waste*r the*r soil?’*r
“But*rp he*r replied*r to*r him,*r ‘Sir,*r leave*r it*r this*r year*r also,*r until*r I*r dig*r around*r it*r and*r fertilize*r it.*r
Perhaps*r it*r will*r produce*r fruit*r next*r year,*r but*r if*r not,*r you*r can*r cut*r it*r down.’”*r
Healing a Daughter of Abraham
As*p he was teaching in one of the synagogues on the Sabbath,
a woman was there who had been disabled by a spirit for over eighteen years. She was bent over and could not straighten up at all.
When Jesus saw her, he called out to her, “Woman,*r you*r are*r free*r of*r your*r disability.”*r
Then he laid his hands on her, and instantly she was restored and began to glorify God.

But*p the leader of the synagogue, indignant because Jesus had healed on the Sabbath, responded by telling the crowd, “There are six days when work should be done; therefore come on those days and be healed and not on the Sabbath day.”

But*p the Lord answered him and said, “Hypocrites!*r Doesn’t*r each*r one*r of*r you*r untie*r his*r ox*r or*r donkey*r from*r the*r feeding*r trough*r on*r the*r Sabbath*r and*r lead*r it*r to*r water?*r
Satan*r has*r bound*r this*r woman,*r a*r daughter*r of*r Abraham,*r for*r eighteen*r years -*r shouldn’t*r she*r be*r untied*r from*r this*r bondage*r on*r the*r Sabbath*r day?”*r
When*p he had said these things, all his adversaries were humiliated, but the whole crowd was rejoicing over all the glorious things he was doing.
The Parables of the Mustard Seed and of the Leaven
He*p said, therefore, “What*r is*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r like,*r and*r what*r can*r I*r compare*r it*r to?*r

It’s*r like*r a*r mustard*r seed*r that*r a*r man*r took*r and*r sowed*r in*r his*r garden.*r It*r grew*r and*r became*r a*r tree,*r and*r the*r birds*r of*r the*r sky*r nested*r in*r its*r branches.”*r
Again*p he said, “What*r can*r I*r compare*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r to?*r
It’s*r like*r leaven*r that*r a*r woman*r took*r and*r mixed*r into*r fifty*r pounds*r of*r flour*r until*r all*r of*r it*r was*r leavened.”*r
The Narrow Way
He*p went through one town and village after another, teaching and making his way to Jerusalem.
“Lord,” someone asked him, “are only a few people going to be saved?” He*p said to them,
“Make*r every*r effort*r to*r enter*r through*r the*r narrow*r door,*r because*r I*r tell*r you,*r many*r will*r try*r to*r enter*r and*r won’t*r be*r able*r

once*r the*r homeowner*r gets*r up*r and*r shuts*r the*r door.*r Then*r you*r will*r stand*r outside*r and*r knock*r on*r the*r door,*r saying,*r ‘Lord,*r open*r up*r for*r us! ’*r He*r will*r answer*r you,*r ‘I*r don’t*r know*r you*r or*r where*r you’re*r from.’*r
Then*r you*r will*r say,*r ‘We*r ate*r and*r drank*r in*r your*r presence,*r and*r you*r taught*r in*r our*r streets.’*r
But*r he*r will*r say,*r ‘I*r tell*r you,*r I*r don’t*r know*r you*r or*r where*r you’re*r from.*r Get*r away*r from*r me,*r all*r you*r evildoers!’*r

There*r will*r be*r weeping*r and*r gnashing*r of*r teeth*r in*r that*r place,*r when*r you*r see*r Abraham,*r Isaac,*r Jacob,*r and*r all*r the*r prophets*r in*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God,*r but*r yourselves*r thrown*r out.*r
They*r will*r come*r from*r east*r and*r west,*r from*r north*r and*r south,*r to*r share*r the*r banquet*r in*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God.*r
Note*r this:*r Some*r who*r are*r last*r will*r be*r first,*r and*r some*r who*r are*r first*r will*r be*r last.”*r
Jesus and Herod Antipas
At*p that time some Pharisees came and told him, “Go, get out of here. Herod wants to kill you.”

He*p said to them, “Go*r tell*r that*r fox,*r ‘Look,*r I’m*r driving*r out*r demons*r and*r performing*r healings*r today*r and*r tomorrow,*r and*r on*r the*r third*r day*r I*r will*r complete*r my*r work.’*r
Yet*r it*r is*r necessary*r that*r I*r travel*r today,*r tomorrow,*r and*r the*r next*r day,*r because*r it*r is*r not*r possible*r for*r a*r prophet*r to*r perish*r outside*r of*r Jerusalem.*r
Jesus’s Lamentation over Jerusalem

“Jerusalem,*rp Jerusalem,*r who*r kills*r the*r prophets*r and*r stones*r those*r who*r are*r sent*r to*r her.*r How*r often*r I*r wanted*r to*r gather*r your*r children*r together,*r as*r a*r hen*r gathers*r her*r chicks*r under*r her*r wings,*r but*r you*r were*r not*r willing!*r

See,*r your*r house*r is*r abandoned*r to*r you.*r I*r tell*r you,*r you*r will*r not*r see*r me*r until*r the*r time*r comes*r when*r you*r say,*r ‘Blessed*ir is*ir he*ir who*ir comes*ir in*ir the*ir name*ir of*ir the*ir Lord*ir ’!”*r
